section.title: What is it?
section.p: The file upload in wyona allows the user to upload arbitrary files to the web server. It is implemented as a cocoon action.

section.title: How does it work
section.p: The basic idea of how it works is as follows:

ol.li: You have a link in your existing document which invokes the upload form and passes it the xpath of itself.
Once you're in the upload form you enter the file name of the file that you want to upload along with some additional (dublin core) information such as description, keywords, title, creator, etc.

The submit button of the form then does a post which is handled in a cocoon action.
The action copies the file into an appropriate directory,
creates a meta xml file that contains all the dublin core metae information for the uploaded file
and inserts a <media> element at the xpath where the originating link was in the requesting document.
After the action the sitemap does a redirect to the original document where the image is now inserted (with appropriate caption, alt tag, etc.).

section.title: How to use it in my publication?
section.p: In order to use the file upload action for your own publication you have to do the following:

ol.li: Add an action and a matcher to your sitemap
Create a form that generates a post request. For that it recomended that you use and possibly adapt upload-image.xsl and upload-image.xsp

section.title: Sitemap
section.p: You need to configure the action in your sitemap and you need to add a pipeline which invokes the action.

section.title: pipeline
section.source: <map:match pattern="upload"> <map:act type="file-upload"> <!-- if the action suceeds it returns the referer and we simply redirect to it. --> <map:redirect-to uri="{$referer}"/> </map:act> <!-- otherwise the action could not validate some of the input and we present the upload form again --> <map:generate type="serverpages" src="../../docs/cms/upload-image.xsp"/> <map:transform src="../../stylesheets/cms/Page/upload-image.xsl"/> <map:serialize type="html"/> </map:match>

section.title: request form
section.p: The request is generated in the html form which is generated using upload-image.xsl and upload-image.xsp. Adapt those if you have different requirements. Make sure you comply with the interfaces outlined below.

section.title: Upload form
section.p: The outline form provides the user with the ability to enter a filename and additional information (according to dublin core) pertaining to this file.

section.title: Interfaces
section.p: The file upload has two interfaces. The configuration interface via the action parameters and the http post parameters which are passed to the action.

dl.dd: <images-dir href="resources/images" /> store the upload images at this path (relative to the publication).
<meta-dir href="docs/metaDir" /> store the xml files containing the meta information (dublin core) for the uploaded file at this path(relative to the publication).
<insert-image-before value="false" /> Insert the media tag before the xpath if true (default). Insert after otherwise.

section.title: Http Request parameters
section.p: The following http request parameters are expected from the action. All parameters are of type text except for the parameter uploadFile which is obvioulsly of type file.

dl.dd: The location at which the image is to be inserted in the document that requested the image upload.
The document id of the document that requested the image upload. This is used to find the xml document where the media tag has to be inserted at the lopcation given by the xpath.
The url of the document that requested the image upload. This is used to redirect back to it once the image upload is done.
Values true or false. Defines if the media element is inserted before or after the given xpath. Overwrites the sitemap configuration parameter insert-image-before if present.

section.p:
Dublin Core meta data parameters (optional):
All these parameters are stored as meta informarion in the meta data file. See the Dublin Core for an explanation of these parameters.

dl.dd: Currently also used as alt tag for the image
Currently also used as authorline tag for the image
Currently also used as media-caption tag for the image
Currently also used as copyright tag for the image

section.title: How to customize
section.p: The easiest way to customize the file upload is probably using the action parameters in the sitemap. The other more powerful possibility is of course subclassing.

section.title: action parameters
section.p: Use the action parameters to change where you want to store the images or the meta data files.

section.title: subclassing
section.p: You might want to subclass the ArticleImageUploadCreatorAction e.g. to add a different media tag or to have the images stored in a different path.

dl.dd: The mime type of the uploaded file is not recognized properly.
(*cough*) There is practically no validation of the request parameters. This is a potential security problem.
Uploading an image and inserting it in a document is editing this document. It should therefore be integrated with the revision controler.
The insertMediaTag method is very specific for the unipublic publication. It should be made more generic.
